'''Victoria Jackson''' (born August 2, 1959)<ref name="filmref 1"/> is an [[United States|American]] actress, comedian, and singer who was a cast member of the [[NBC]] television [[sketch comedy]] series ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' (SNL) from 1986 to 1992. From 2008 to 2017, Jackson was politically active as part of the [[Tea Party movement]]. Jackson's autobiography, ''Is My Bow Too Big? How I went from Saturday Night Live to the Tea Party'' was published in 2012.
==Early life== Jackson was born in [[Miami, Florida]], the daughter of Marlene Esther (née Blackstad) and James McCaslin Jackson, a gym coach.<ref name="filmref 1">{{cite web|url=http://www.filmreference.com/film/32/Victoria-Jackson.html|title=Victoria Jackson biography (1959 -)|work=Theatre, Film, and Television Biographies|publisher=FilmReference.com|accessdate=March 27, 2010}}</ref> From the age of 5 until she was 18, Jackson's father trained her in gymnastics.<ref name="Tenessean2014">{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2014/03/18/victoria-jackson-conservative-values/6585043/|title=Victoria Jackson's values no laughing matter|last1=Page|first1=Jamie|date=March 18, 2014|newspaper=The Tennessean |location=Nashville |via=''USA Today'' }}</ref>
Following high school graduation, Jackson attended Florida Bible College in [[Hollywood, Florida]], later transferring to [[Furman University]] in [[Greenville, South Carolina]] on a gymnastics scholarship. At Furman, she was cast in her first play. She transferred to [[Auburn University]] in 1979 for her senior year, changing her major to theater. Midway through her senior year, she left Auburn to pursue an acting career.<ref name="Tenessean2014" /><ref>{{cite news|last1=Henderson|first1=Jeremy|title=SNL alum Victoria Jackson's year at Auburn|url=http://www.thewareaglereader.com/2014/10/snl-alum-victoria-jackson-loved-auburn-auburn-didnt-love-her-back-war-eagle/|work=The War Eagle Reader|date=October 16, 2014}}</ref>
In the 2000s, Jackson earned a degree in theatre from [[Palm Beach Atlantic University]].<ref name="NewTimes" />
==Acting and comedy== While doing summer stock theater in Alabama, Jackson met former child-actor [[Johnny Crawford]] of the 1950s television series, ''[[The Rifleman]]'', who cast her in his nightclub act. She moved to Los Angeles in 1981,<ref name=LAT1084>{{cite news | last1=Barber | first1=Mary | title=Bottom Lines: Gymnast-Actress and Fire-Eating Musician Make Their Dreams Come True | work=Los Angeles Times | date=16 August 1984}}</ref> working various day jobs while performing comedy at night.<ref name=tulsaworld/><ref name=Globe1984>{{cite news | last1=Montville | first1=Leigh | title=Adventures in the L.A. skim trade | work=Boston Globe | date=July 29, 1984}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last1=Damsker | first1=Matt | title='Rainbow Of Comedy' Coming To San Diego: Stand-Up Comics Set For Old Globe Stand-Up Comics | work=Los Angeles Times | date=1 November 1983 | quote=Opening for each of these headliners is an assortment of lesser-known stand-ups. ranging from ... comic poet-acrobat Victoria Jackson,...}}</ref> Her first big break was her appearance on ''[[The Tonight Show Starring Johnny Carson]]'', where she performed doing a handstand while reciting poetry.<ref name=tulsaworld/><ref>{{cite news|last1=Berger|first1=Phil|title=The New Comediennes|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/29/magazine/the-new-comediennes.html?pagewanted=all|work=The New York Times|date=29 July 1984}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last1=Daltry | first1=Laura | title='Tonight Show' Special: Women, 19 Cents A Pound | work=Los Angeles Times | date=19 August 1984}}</ref> She would go on to appear on the show twenty times.<ref name=tulsaworld/> In 1984 she appeared in the pilot for ''[[W*A*L*T*E*R]]'', a failed ''[[M*A*S*H (TV series)|M*A*S*H]]'' spin-off that the networks did not pick up.<ref>{{Citation | last=Arielle Miranda Seaboard | title=W*A*L*T*E*R clip featuring Victoria Jackson | date=2015-11-20 | url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HcqummksfjM&feature=youtu.be | access-date=2018-08-28}}</ref> In the pilot episode she was listed in the end-credits as "Victoria Carroll".<ref>{{Citation | last=TW Walker | title=WALTER - Pilot | date=2013-06-07 | url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OS8Vd1vVqXc&feature=youtu.be | access-date=2018-08-28}}</ref>
Following a role in the short-lived 1985 television series ''[[Half Nelson (TV series)|Half Nelson]]'',<ref>{{cite web|title=Half Nelson - Television Obscurities|url=http://www.tvobscurities.com/spotlight/half-nelson/|website=Television Obscurities|accessdate=7 January 2018}}</ref> Jackson received an offer to audition for the cast of ''[[Saturday Night Live]]''. Because she was not confident her audition had gone well, on her next appearance on ''The Tonight Show'' she performed several impersonations and sent the tape to ''SNL''{{'}}s [[Lorne Michaels]]. After viewing the tape, Michaels asked Jackson to join the show.<ref name=Casual/><ref>{{cite book | last1=Miller | first1=James Andrew | last2=Shales | first2=Tom | title=Live From New York: The Complete, Uncensored History of Saturday Night Live as Told by Its Stars, Writers, and Guests | date=2014 | publisher=Little, Brown | isbn=9780316295079 | pages=301ff | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KoNUBAAAQBAJ&pg=PT301 | language=en}}</ref> A regular cast member from 1986 to 1992,<ref name=Herald2005/> Jackson often appeared on the show's weekly ''[[Weekend Update]]'' segment as a correspondent who would go off-topic, reciting poetry and doing back-bends or handstands on the desk<ref name=NewTimes/><ref name=Casual/> Jackson was also known for her recurring skit roles where she would impersonate [[Roseanne Barr]] or [[Zsa Zsa Gabor]].<ref name=NewTimes/> She was one of the few women on the show.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Kahn|first1=Eve|title=Television; Women in the Locker Room At 'Saturday Night Live'|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/02/16/arts/television-women-in-the-locker-room-at-saturday-night-live.html|work=The New York Times|date=16 February 1992}}</ref>
During her tenure on ''SNL'', Jackson was cast in a number of films including ''[[Baby Boom (film)|Baby Boom]]'', ''[[Family Business (film)|Family Business]]'', and ''[[I Love You to Death]]''<ref name=Herald2005/> as well as ''[[UHF (film)|UHF]]'',<ref name="tulsaworld"/> ''[[The Pick-up Artist (film)|The Pick-up Artist]]'',<ref>{{cite news|last1=Thomas|first1=Kevin|title=Movie Reviews: 'Pick-up Artist' Meets His Match|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1987-09-19/entertainment/ca-2169_1_artist-pick-movie|work=Los Angeles Times|date=19 September 1987}}</ref> ''[[The Couch Trip]]'',<ref>{{cite news|title=The Couch Trip|url=http://www.1988infilm.com/uncategorized/the-couch-trip/|work=1988 In Film|date=July 9, 2015|language=en}}</ref> and ''[[Casual Sex?]]''<ref name=Casual>{{cite news | last1=Beale | first1=Lewis | title=A Christian Fundamentalist Disrobes For ''Casual Sex?'' | url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1988-04-28/features/8803120601_1_fundamentalist-gymnastics-christian | work=Los Angeles Daily News | via=''Chicago Tribune'' | date=April 28, 1988 | language=en}}</ref>
Jackson's film career continued following her 1992 departure from ''Saturday Night Live'', however her roles were in mostly unknown or unnoticed films.<ref name="filmref 1" /> On television, she was cast as the lead of her own sitcom co-starring [[George Clooney]]. When there was a change in management at Fox, the show was scrapped without being broadcast.<ref name="tulsaworld">{{cite news|url=http://www.tulsaworld.com/archives/snl-alum-brings-stand-up-routine-to-tulsa-club/article_3128c31f-4493-580f-8025-72fbcf7eb2bf.html |title='SNL' alum brings stand-up routine to Tulsa club |first=Robert S. |last=Walters |date=November 11, 1999 |newspaper=[[Tulsa World]]}}</ref> In 1994 she appeared as "Beverly" in the ''[[In the Heat of the Night (TV series)|In the Heat of the Night]]''<ref>{{cite web|title=In the Heat of the Night, Season 7, Episode 13 Good Cop, Bad Cop|url=http://www.tvguide.com/tvshows/in-the-heat-of-the-night/episode-13-season-7/good-cop-bad-cop/202207/|accessdate=7 January 2018|work=TVGuide|language=en}}</ref> episode, "Good Cop, Bad Cop", and in 2000 she appeared as the unrequited love of a small-town man who can control the weather in ''[[The X-Files]]'' episode, "[[The Rain King (The X-Files)|The Rain King]]".<ref>{{cite book | year=2000 | author=Meisler, Andy | title= The End and the Beginning: The Official Guide to the X-Files Season 6 |isbn= 0-06-107595-7 |publisher=HarperCollins|pages=80–89 }}</ref>
During the 2003–2004 seasons, Jackson had a regular role in the Nickelodeon show ''[[Romeo!]]''.<ref name=Herald2005>{{cite news|last1=Gehrke-White|first1=Donna|title=Ex-'SNL' star Victoria Jackson balances career, motherhood|url=http://www.heraldextra.com/entertainment/ex--snl-star-victoria-jackson-balances-career-motherhood/article_3ecfac0d-60c6-5f5e-95c5-ae2540032f08.html|work=Daily Herald|date=October 28, 2005|language=en}}</ref> In 2004 and 2005 she had roles in two romantic comedies, ''[[Shut Up and Kiss Me (film)|Shut Up and Kiss Me!]]'' and ''[[Her Minor Thing]]''.<ref name=Herald2005/> During this period, Jackson appeared on the game show ''[[Hollywood Squares]]'', and participated in the show ''[[Celebrity Fit Club (U.S. TV series)|Celebrity Fit Club]]''.<ref name=Herald2005/> She played multiple characters in the 2014 [[direct-to-video]] movie, ''Campin' Buddies''.<ref name=Stokes>{{cite news|last1=Stokes|first1=Justin|title=Victoria Jackson talks Tea Party, Zanies show|url=http://www.tennessean.com/story/life/2015/10/07/victoria-jackson-talks-tea-party-zanies-show/73476888/|work=The Tennessean|date=October 7, 2015|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=McLevy|first1=Alex|title=Nothing says "garbage movie" like Victoria Jackson in 7 different roles|url=https://film.avclub.com/nothing-says-garbage-movie-like-victoria-jackson-in-7-1798257007|work=Film|date=January 30, 2017}}</ref>
In 2016, Jackson had a role in ''[[The Matchbreaker (2016 film)|The Matchbreaker]]''.<ref name=Stokes/>

Jackson's run resulted in 632 votes, not enough to secure either seat against the incumbent candidates.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Page|first1=Jamie|title=Former SNL star Victoria Jackson officially files for county commission|url=http://www.tennessean.com/story/news/local/williamson/thompsons-station/2014/02/19/former-snl-star-victoria-jackson-officially-files-for-county-commission/5617867/|work=The Tennessean via USAToday|date=February 19, 2014|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title='SNL's Victoria Jackson falls to incumbents|url=http://www.tennessean.com/story/news/politics/2014/08/07/snls-victoria-jackson-falls-incumbents/13755741/|work=The Tennesseean|date=August 7, 2014}}</ref>
In 2017, Jackson dropped out of politics.<ref name=WND2017/>
==Personal life== She married a fellow performer, a [[fire eating|fire-eater]], in 1984,<ref name=LAT1084/> and had a daughter with him; they divorced in 1991.<ref name=NewTimes/> Shortly after her divorce, Jackson reconnected with her high school sweetheart, then a Miami-Dade SWAT-team police officer.<ref name=Tenessean2014/> When her husband retired in 2013, the couple moved to Nashville, Tennessee.<ref name=Tenessean2014/><ref name=CBN>{{cite news|title=Victoria Jackson: Funny Begins with Faith|url=http://www1.cbn.com/victoria-jackson-funny-begins-faith|work=The Christian Broadcasting Network|date=October 2017}}</ref>
In 2017 BroadStreet Publishing released a comedy/devotional about Jackson's cancer journey, ''"Lavender Hair.''"<ref name=WND2017>{{cite news|last1=Jackson|first1=Victoria|title=Why Victoria Jackson dropped out of politics|url=http://www.wnd.com/2017/10/why-victoria-jackson-dropped-out-of-politics/|work=WND|date=October 11, 2017}}</ref>

Esther Rosenberg

Rachel Brown | relatives = | influences = | influenced = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | website = | portaldisp = }} '''William Slater Brown''' (November 13, 1896 – June 22, 1997) was an American novelist, biographer, and translator of French literature. Most notably, he was a friend of the [[poet]] [[E. E. Cummings]] and is best known as the character "B." in Cumming's 1922 memoir/novel ''[[The Enormous Room]]''. His books, published under the name Slater Brown, include the novel ''The Burning Wheel'' (1943); ''[[Ethan Allen]] and the [[Green Mountain Boys]]'' (1956), a biography for children; and ''The Heyday of Spiritualism'' (1970), a study of the 19th-century interest in [[parapsychology]] and the [[occult]]. ==Early life== Brown was born to the physician Frederick Augustus Brown and Katharine Slater in the town of [[Webster, Massachusetts]]. His great-great grandfather, businessman [[Samuel Slater]], was the chief founder of Webster and is credited with beginning the industrial revolution in the United States with the opening of [[Slater Mill Historic Site | a textile mill]] in [[Pawtucket, Rhode Island]] in 1790.{{Cite web |url= http://www.gvsu.edu/english/cummings/Brown1.htm |title=William Slater Brown and the Enormous Room |work=gvsu.edu |accessdate=August 30, 2010 }} Early family wealth disappeared through a series of misfortunes, and Brown and his younger siblings, Fritz, Joyce and Kitty, grew up in relative poverty. From the age of 16, while living with cousins in Boston, the rebellious Brown adopted a life and world philosophy at odds to that of his parents, and he undertook a process of self-discovery that led him to a failed enrollment at [[Columbia School of Journalism]].{{Cite web |url = http://www.gvsu.edu/english/cummings/Collier6.htm |title = "B" (William Slater Brown) |work = gvsu.edu |accessdate = August 30, 2010 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110217073624/http://www.gvsu.edu/english/cummings/Collier6.htm |archivedate = February 17, 2011 |df = mdy-all }} ==World War I== Brown volunteered to serve in the [[American Volunteer Motor Ambulance Corps|Norton-Harjes Ambulance Corps]] in early 1917. En route to [[France]] aboard the {{SS|La Touraine}} he met E.E. Cummings. Due to an organizational mix-up, the two spent five weeks together in [[Paris]] before assigned to an [[ambulance]] unit, during which time they became close friends. In September 1917 Brown and Cummings were arrested on suspicion of espionage and were imprisoned at the [[La Ferté-Macé]] [[detention camp]], [[Orne]], [[Normandy]]. Cummings was released in December 1917 after intervention from his father; however, Brown was not released at the same time, and in fact was transferred at that time to a prison in [[Précigné]]. Brown was not able to secure his release for three additional months, after which he sailed for New York, where he reunited with Cummings. ==Later life== Brown later became part of the [[Bohemianism|bohemian circle]] of artists and writers in [[Greenwich Village]], New York, contributing articles and reviews to magazines and journals such as ''[[The New Masses]]'' and ''[[The Dial]]''. These years were marked by his struggle with alcoholism which he finally overcame in 1947. During this time he married Susan Jenkins, who was part of the [[Provincetown Players]] group, and they had one son, Gwilym Slater Brown (1928–1974). His daughter, Rachel Brown, was born to Esther Rosenberg in 1936. In 1957 he married Mary James (died 1987), the granddaughter of Robertson James and grandniece of [[Henry James]]. They resided in [[Rockport, Massachusetts]]. William Slater Brown died at age 100 in 1997. ==See also== *[[List of ambulance drivers during World War I]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/28/arts/william-slater-brown-100-writer-of-the-lost-generation.html "William Slater Brown, 100, Writer of the Lost Generation"] ''[[New York Times]]'' *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110217073624/http://www.gvsu.edu/english/cummings/Collier6.htm "B (William Slater Brown)"] from ''Spring: The Journal of the E.
